title: 103_s1566
content: The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act of 1993, also known as the Rent-To-Own Protection Act, is an amendment to the Consumer Credit Protection Act. It introduces Title X, which focuses on regulating rent-to-own transactions. The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act, also known as the Rent-To-Own Protection Act, aims to regulate the rent-to-own industry. It targets low-income and minority neighborhoods, where customers often intend to own the goods they are renting. However, dealers frequently fail to disclose contract terms and engage in unfair debt collection practices, lacking the protections provided in retail sales. The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act aims to provide protections to consumers in rent-to-own transactions, similar to those in retail sales. It requires disclosure of contract terms and prohibits abusive collection practices by dealers and their agents. The Act defines terms like "cash price" to ensure transparency in transactions. The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act defines terms like "Commission," "consumer," and "credit" to ensure transparency in rent-to-own transactions. The Act aims to provide protections to consumers and prohibits abusive collection practices by dealers and their agents. The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act defines terms like "organization" as a legal entity and outlines the calculation of the fixed sum in rent-to-own contracts. The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act defines key terms such as 'person' as a natural person or organization, 'rent-to-own contract' as a terminable lease of consumer goods with an option for ownership transfer, 'rent-to-own transaction' as the lease of consumer goods under such a contract, and 'seller' as a person who regularly deals in consumer goods. The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act prohibits sellers in rent-to-own transactions from charging interest, finance charges, or fees that exceed the limits set by the state laws where the seller is located. This applies to individuals or organizations who offer consumer goods under rent-to-own contracts, as well as their assignees. The term 'State' includes any state, Puerto Rico, the District of Columbia, and U.S. territories. The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act regulates fees in rent-to-own transactions, including termination fees and recovery fees for items not returned. The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act limits termination fees to 5% of the cash price disclosed in the contract and requires disclosure of termination and recovery fees. Termination of a rent-to-own contract with a termination fee satisfies the consumer's obligations for all payments and fees, except those due before termination. The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act limits termination fees to 5% of the cash price disclosed in the contract and requires disclosure of termination and recovery fees. Guarantees and warranties applicable to goods sold in consumer credit sales also apply to rent-to-own transactions. Federal laws such as the Truth in Lending Act, Equal Credit Opportunity Act, and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act apply to rent-to-own transactions. The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act mandates disclosures on goods in rent-to-own transactions, including cash price, services offered, annual percentage rate, and payment details. The Fair Credit Reporting Act applies to credit transactions in rent-to-own agreements. The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act requires disclosures on goods in rent-to-own transactions, including payment details, total payments required, and whether the item is new or used. Prohibitions under the Act include threats of criminal prosecution, coercion to collect payments, and conduct that oppresses or harasses consumers. The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act prohibits unfair debt collection practices, deceptive representations, and advertising services as free when charges apply under the contract. Federal law enforcement by the Commission ensures compliance with the Act, with powers similar to those under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act prohibits unfair debt collection practices and deceptive advertising. Violations of the Act result in civil liability, including damages to the consumer, fines, and attorney fees. The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act allows actions to be brought in any court of competent jurisdiction within 2 years of the violation. The statute of limitations does not prevent asserting a violation as a defense in a collection action after 2 years. Regulations must be issued within 6 months of enactment, and the Act does not limit other available remedies under State or Federal law. The Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act exempts individuals from state laws on rent-to-own transactions, unless they conflict with the Act. The Truth in Lending Act's consumer lease provisions do not apply to rent-to-own transactions if they conflict with the Rent-To-Own Consumer Credit Protection Act. The Federal Trade Commission must provide Congress with recommendations for further action on regulating rent-to-own transactions within 2 years of this Act's enactment. The provisions and amendments of this Act will take effect immediately upon enactment.
